Award.AwardTitle: CNH: The Effects of China's Grain-for-Green Program on the Dynamics of Coupled Natural-Human System in Rural China
Award.AbstractNarration:
Perverse economic effects can create strong negative feedbacks between natural and human systems. For example, short-term, fine-scale, net economic benefits from uses of natural resources that compromise the future supply of related resources can reduce long-term, large-scale economic benefits. Numerous governmental programs have effectively tested the hypothesis that such negative feedbacks can be eliminated with economic counter-incentives, but few if any of these programs have been suitable for and subjected to the rigorous scientific analysis needed to determine the true results of the test and help generalize results. This project will analyze what is probably the largest program within the most widely used type of counter-incentive, the Sloping Lands Conversion Program of China, a program of payment for environmental services. Under this program, the government pays farmers to convert cropland on sloping or otherwise ecologically sensitive areas to forest or grassland. Researchers will survey farmers and local governmental agencies in three provinces to determine how the program was implemented and affected the decisions of farmers, detect changes in land cover using satellite imagery, and model carbon storage and water availability based on field measurements.

Results of this project will be of great value to policy makers and land use managers in the U.S., where similar programs have been tried and are envisioned in the context of ecological restoration and protection. The research also will help inform the global discourse on reducing carbon emissions from deforestation and forest degradation. This project will strengthen scientific collaboration in both social and natural science between the U.S. and China, and train numerous undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: This is an international collaborative project with the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill being the lead research institute and Beijing Forestry University, Anhui Agricultural University and Wuhan Botanical Garden as the partners in China. The objectives of the project include (1) understanding the socioeconomic impacts of the Grain-for-Green reforestation program, (2) the ecological impacts of the reforestation program, and (3) the feedbacks of the environmental changes from reforestation program to the human systems. We conducted household surveys in two contrasting study sites, a subtropical site in Anhui Province and a semi-arid site in Shanxi Province in China to understand the socioeconomic impacts and the environmental feedbacks to the human system. We developed a series of modeling tools to analyze the environmental consequences of the reforestation program.

Intellectual Merit: With the support of this grant, three waves of household surveys were conducted, and we collected  socioeconomic data  for more than 1,000 households with an innovative sampling technique. The most significant findings include: (1) The Grain-for-Green reforestation program has been a very successful program. The majority of the reforested cropland will remain forested even after the program compensation ends; (2) the Grain-for-Green reforestation program had significantly stimulated out-migration due to labor release from the cropland; (3) Enhanced crop raiding by wildlife, causing serious loss from the crop damage for farmers,  was found to be an unexpected consequence of the Grain-for-Green program as a result of improved forest conditions; (4) We found China’s vegetation demonstrated a strong greening trend, but globally vegetation greening does not lead to proportional increase in carbon storage as the majority of the greening comes from cropland expansion, which has very limited capacity for carbon storage; (5) We developed numerous modeling tools to understand the consequences of land-cover/land-use change (e.g. reforestation) in the context of climate change.

Broader Impact:  (1) The project fully supported one graduate student to obtain the PhD degree, and partially supported four other PhD students in their graduate studies, and two post-doctoral fellows at the University of North Carolina at UNC Chapel Hill.  (2) The project provided a research opportunity to one visiting scholar from China who wrote the dissertation based on the data collected by the project, and obtained the PhD degree in China. (3) With the project support, we trained several dozen graduate and undergraduate students from both the US and China on how to conduct household survey. (4) Our findings of the socioeconomic effects of the Grain-for-Green reforestation program are highly valuable for the Chinese government for program assessment as well as for designing an improved similar program in the future. As of this time, we published 12 peer-reviewed  articales (more in the pipeline) on top international journals (e.g. Global Change Biology, Remote Sensing of Environment, Ecological Economics, Land Use Policy, Forest Policy and Economics). (5) We also disseminated our research findings at the annual meetings of American Association of Geographers and American Geophysical Union each year during the project life. We organized two Symposia in collaboration with our Chinese partners in China on understanding the dynamics of coupled natural and human systems with scholars from both the US and China. We also presented our research findings in the 2015 International Forestry Congress.
